Cheers my lads!  Looking for suggestions to optimize this Ranger.
 
The Warden Vindicator (Ehlonna’s Retribution)
Race: Human (other races work but incur xp penalties)
Alignment: Any
Classes: Ranger32/Fighter4/Rogue4
Playable: 1-40, PvM, Low to Mid Magic

7 Ranger7

10 Ranger10, FE III
11 Ranger11

13 Ranger13

34 Ranger27
35 Ranger28

37 Rogue4
38 Ranger30, FE, VII
39 Ranger31, Epic Will
40 Ranger32, FE VIII, Str30
 
Combat Vitals
AB: 44/39/34/29
Naked AC: 22
Mundane Armor/ Shield: 32
Base Max HP: 504
Dev Crit DC: 40 (46 max)
Bane AB w/Aid & Blade Thirst: 50/45/40/35
 
Saves
Fort: 24
Will: 22
Reflex: 18
 
Total Skill Points: 300
Animal Empathy - 24
Hide - 40 
Move Silently - 43 
Set Trap – 43
Craft Trap - 15 (this might need tweaking)
Tumble - 40
UMD - 30
Disable Trap - 28
Search - 17
Spot
Open Lock – 10
Spot - 1
Heal - 1
 
Preferred FEs: Reptilian Humanoids, Goblinoids, Giants, Undead, Outsiders, Drow, Humans, Elementals
 
Ranger Spell Set
1st: Ultravision, Camouflage (lasts forever), 2 Summons (for Bigby Bait)
2nd: Cat’s Grace, One with Land, Protection from Elements
3rd: Blade Thirst (works on all weapons up to +5 enhancement), Aid, Greater Magic Fang
4th: Freedom, Summons IV (x2) for Ikes Yikes sponging
 
Strengths
·       Strong offensive output; attains Bane of Enemies and Dev Crit by Level 28 and EWS by Level 33
·       Evasion
·       Use Magic Device
·       Versatile Enough to use Hide Armor and Tower Shield (doesn’t have to wait on Heavy Armor proficiency)
·       Stealth Skills augmented by Camouflage and One with Land
·       Knockdown for Casters
·       Great Skill Set
·       Undispellable Ranger Spells
·       8 Favored Enemies
 
Weaknesses
Mediocre AC
Lowish Saves (augmented with Evasion, Freedom, Aid, and Protection from Elements)
 
Commentary
I checked the old archives and didn’t see a Build with this set-up, but I’m not sure where to check for newer entries, so if I missed it please forgive me and the Moderators may remove this entry.  I wanted a Ranger that had both Dev Crit and Bane early on in Epic.  On WoG, Rangers receive 6 skill points per level, so it liberates Rangers from having to go for the inevitable 14 Intelligence.  Having this freedom allows the Ranger to actually focus on more rangerly pursuits.
 
It’s been awhile since I dipped my foot into the pool of actual building, but I’ve been itching to play Rangers again.  What I have forgotten is that Rangers mustn’t be played in the same vein as normal melee builds.  They must be played like an assassin.  You camo up, you stalk your prey and then strike!  It also pays to go after your FE’s.  Don’t go running off to the Steading of the Hill Giant Chief if you haven’t acquired your FE Giants yet, and so on.  Craft traps, recover traps, find traps, and use them to disable your prey.  Use your Panther Companion as a secondary assault when you spring your trap.  Engage your opponent head on then call your panther (Cat Graced, Greater Fanged, Flame Berried, and Stone-skinned using Gargoyle Boots) and have him deal devastating flanking sneaks while you knock your opponent down.
 
The Dev Crit is an insurance policy.  This will help clear out the mobs and allow you to focus on the things that matter.
 
In playtesting from the ground up, I never bothered to dualwield.  I used Chain Shirt and supplement my Dex to make up for any AC shortfalls (Chain Shirt grants 4 AC, and you can supplement another 4 AC if you get you Dexterity up to 18, which is relatively easy to do with your base 14 Dex and Cat’s Grace.  I also supplemented AC with a Tower Shield.  He is also able to effective stealth in medium/light armor & shield by augmenting his natural Stealth skills with Camouflage and One with Land.
 
Battle Axe was chosen for style, but one could choose from any of the one-handed martial/simple weapons.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Wow!

GD!!!!!

Be still, my palpitating heart!

What about Assassin instead of Rogue?  There is some good synergy there - although evil.

I want to draw your attention to something I noticed about Rangers (Animal Companions) :

Badger
30 1d10/1d10/2d8 +3 +3 20/+1
35 1d12/1d12/2d10 +4 +4 20/+2
40 2d8/2d8/2d12 +5 +5 20/+3
Now, I did not know this little "tidbit" of info, and I have been playing Rangers since NWN was released!

Combined with a certain item for Animal Companions on WoG, that as revealed by DM Wise adds Regeneration as well as elemental damage to an Animal Companion, and WOW!

You have an Animal Companion that can Greater Rage (at max amount due to the Ranger levels here) PLUS the best DR PLUS Regen (+5 Regen??!!  Holy crud!!!! O_o ) AND then add in the Regen from the item AND then give your Badger an item that also adds Regen...the mind boggles at this!

+7~8 Regen a round, combined with some pretty nice DR...THIS is EPIC!

Wouldn't it be worth somehow getting to level 35 Ranger, just for this?  That would still leave you the 4 Fighter levels for the WS, etc, and 1 level over for perhaps SD1?

BTW - this has me drooling...gotta go out and test this!

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
Thanks for the suggestions, everyone.  I realize I hung up my cleats years ago, but I still play from time to time and I still build a bit, but it’s mostly off the record kind of stuff.  This has been my first attempt at a formalized build since my Ruinous Devastation.
 
@Orion: Regarding taking Weapon Focus earlier – a few others mentioned this as well, and that’s sound advice.  However, I did have a reason for taking it later.  In fact, I was actually considering pushing it back even further (around 9th) and I’ll explain why.  I hate to be married to a particular weapon early on.  I tend to let the rhythm of the environment dictate what I’ll choose.  On Greyhawk, some of the best weapons in game are ones that are dynamically created in a rare random drop.  I’ve always hated taking weapon focus in something early on only to find an amazing “x weapon” that could have carried me into Epics.  Often times such weapons don’t even bear an Enhancement value, but Rangers can compensate with their versatile Blade Thirst.  But yes, if I were married to a weapon early on, I would take Weapon Focus at Level 3 and not Level 6
 
Regarding Epic Will vs Anything Else – yes, in my original Half-Orc version (before settling on Human), I had Epic Skill Focus: Craft Trap.  The DC for Epic traps is 55 (iirc).  I then waffled on whether this really had long term value since I wouldn’t achieve it until the twilight of the character’s career.  Of course, one could argue that there is diminishing returns for Epic Will at Level 39, or any feat for that matter, but something must be chosen.  I don’t believe there’s much value other than an Epic Save feat, or an Epic Skill Focus, at Level 39.  You may talk me into going the Epic Skill Focus route, though that will require me to put more points into Craft Trap in order to get close to that 55 DC. 
 
To facilitate such, I most likely would drop Con to 12 and bump Int to 12, but I do like having the raw 500 hp Ranger.  He is low on defense, so he has to make up for it somewhere.  Or, I could re-allocate my current skill point distribution.  Looking at what I have listed, there isn’t anything I would care to make lower.  One could argue Animal Empathy, but I make good use of this pre-epic, particularly between Level 5-15 when I can lock down Dire Bears and Ancient Dire Bears.  And while your suggestion on lowering Dex to 12 is worth consideration, bear in mind I don’t plan on wearing Heavy Armor for a very long time, if ever, and on WoG AC matters, especially pre-epic.  Surprisingly, there are ways to make up for this on the back end by way of items.  There are ways to acquire or even craft your own items to make up for Skill score shortfalls.  For instance, with a mediocre socket item, one could gradually make an item that added skill bonus to Craft Trap, Set Trap, and Disable Trap.  It might take a while, but it would be a side project that your character would work on over the course of their career.
 
@Webshaman:  I didn’t know that about the Badger either!  That’s good to know.  Now I want to get in there and see what the other animals have under the hood.  I’ve always enjoyed using the Panther.  If used properly, it’s a great damage delivery system.
 
@Stagmeister, see the above regarding my thoughts on the Weapon Focus feat.  Also, regarding Cleave, I find having Cleave at Level 1 and 2 far more valuable than Weapon Focus.  It’s a quasi-extra attack, which is far more useful at low levels when you only have one.  Unless I don’t have a choice, I typically grab Cleave early on when the design calls for it, and I always regret not having it when I choose WF instead.
 
Also, regarding your suggestion for a 33 UMD, I was actually considering dropping UMD to 26.  Anything that I want to UMD I can effectively do with a modified score of 25.  Unless you have a compelling reason to take it higher, I’ll probably reduce it and bump Craft Trap up few notches.
 
@gkorjax:  I am unable to attain IKD in this build.  One needs a raw 13 Intelligence.  If I could, I would, your right, but alas it is not meant to be.  KD is enough for most medium-sized casters.
 
Finally, someone mentioned taking Assassin over Rogue.  That is a viable option if one is interested in using a Different Race – Dwarf comes to mind in that situation.  In so doing, you would lose Evasion and about 16 skill points, and you would have to lock in on an evil alignment.  The benefit would be the Use Poison feat, which I do like, and poison has a bit more teeth on WoG than regular environments. 
 
Thank you, everyone.  You certainly have given me much to consider.  I think you all hit on those areas on which I remain undecided.  Admittedly this is not a supreme wipe-the-floor-with-the-carcasses-of-your-enemies type of build, but it certainly has enough versatility to deal with most situations.  I think bringing the Craft Trap score up to around 40, and swapping Epic Will with ESF: Craft Trap, are worthy.  In so doing, I would probably take the ESF much earlier (but not at the expense of BoE or Dev Crit progression) in order to get earlier access to some of these trap creations.  In so doing, I’ll probably drop Constitution to 12 and raise Intelligence to 12.  This will garner about 8 skill points per level, and give the player a bit more flexibility with Skill Point allocation. 
 
Thanks again!
